posts.name: Alexander Yngling
posts.cooked:
I recently purchased a Surface Go tablet/laptop, which comes with Windows 10S, which is a version of Windows that only allows installation of apps from the Microsoft Store. Microsoft is pushing this version of Windows pretty hard because of various benefits for businesses and users.

The only app I would want installed on that device that I could not find on the Microsoft Store was Signal.

It would be great for all Windows 10S users if it was possible to add the Signal Windows desktop app to the store.

posts.name: Salt
posts.cooked:
While I understand that some may want to stay on 10 S, it’s easy enough to switch to the normal Windows 10 and install whatever you want.

Tutorial:

urtech.ca

posts.name: Andres Muniz Piniella
posts.cooked:
Windows 11 also has S version. Not having signal in the store is seen as not secure.

Removing the S in windows is similar to running developer mode just to install the app on Android. A little worst because in windows there is no going back to S mode once you deactivated.

Coming back to this after finding a very informative issue on the repo.

posts.name: Scotty
posts.cooked: Since all the other posts to this are older. I’ll make another. Microsoft no longer requires an app to be UWP. This would help spread this app even more. In the future, we should be able to make a UWP app so people with touch screens have an easier time using it.

Just for the record, Signal’s Evan Hahn said this on GitHub about three weeks ago:

This is something that’s on our radar. No promises yet, but this is something we’d eventually like to do.

This would be very appreciated feature. Having it automatically updated in the background as well as security - database files not be easily accessible to other apps - would be great addition to desktop app.

posts.name: Aditya patil
posts.cooked:
this is a must feature for the newbies of who want to Really chat securely.
1.With ms store its easy to install.
2.The exe. installation is clean but still some fancy people do really get some fancy problems.
3.It will be better for releasing updates and user will get auto-updates hassle free

$4. IMPORTANT- people will start to trust. since uploading app to authorized stores makes the app more legit.

hope the hardwork of creators will be applauded on ms store soon…

Necessary to have Signal in the Microsoft store if you use Windows in S mode. Currently these uses are precluded from using Signal Desktop.

image1382×298 71.9 KB

link_counts.title: Windows 10 and Windows 11 in S mode FAQ

posts.cooked:
Hi I would also like to see Signal on the Microsoft Store.

I don’t expect it to replace the standalone version, but in addition to.

I like that Microsoft Store apps are Sandboxed, to lessen the chances of Malware slipping through

I like that Microsoft Store apps are auto updated, without having to press anything.

I like that Microsoft Store apps encourages a safe way to load apps rather than running random EXE files from the Internet

posts.name: Jeremy
posts.cooked: Signal desktop though isn’t a random exe from the internet.

Yes, I know. It encourages bad security practice. To a novice user what is to separate the good from the bad.

Too many times I have seen Software being re-hosted on third party websites and advertised via. Google/Bing Search Ads where the user has heard of a piece of software, thinks that they are downloading the real thing, but actually it is not. If it is listed on the Official platform Store, then it is easy to be on the straight and narrow path without pressing a fake ‘Download’ button.

Sorry that not everyone is as good with computers as we are.

posts.name: Rémy Di Giovanni
posts.cooked:
Publishing on official store would be a great idea, not only for locked editions of windows.
WhatsApp and Facebook messenger are available on the Microsoft store and Apple app store, that makes Users feel safer.
In addition to that there has recently been a review of the requirement and conditions for publishing on the store which should make it easier for developers.

posts.name: user
posts.cooked:
WhatsApp and Facebook messenger are available on the Microsoft store and Apple app store, that makes Users feel safer.

It doesn’t help that you “Feel safer” if you are installing spyware

posts.name: Rémy Di Giovanni
posts.cooked:
I don’t see the connection.
The point of downloading from “official store” is actually to avoid spyware…

posts.name: user
posts.cooked: Facebook is spyware. Just because it says “Official Microsoft Store” doesn’t mean it isn’t spying on everything you do. The same thing goes for Windows and Apple

posts.name: Rémy Di Giovanni
posts.cooked:
I thought that facebook desktop app was discontinued in favour of the web app…
Anyway as far as I know facebook isn’t the only app available on the store.
Downloading the app from the web instead of Microsoft Store does not mean they have fewer access to your datas…
If you do not trust Microsoft, you should run linux on your PC… Then most of the linux distro that I know have a store for example Ubuntu software center, which, if I’m not mistaking is verified by the community. In the case of Microsoft, the review is made by “professional”, such analysis, community or professional, is supposed to prevent viruses to get on your computer which leads me to say it is safer to download from a store.

Then apple isn’t the best example of spying company, they actually make easier for custormer to know the datas the app takes.

Capture d’écran 2022-03-05 2118231914×1992 372 KB

Furthermore if you don’t want to download the app from the store you will probably remain free to do it from the official web site…

posts.name: user
posts.cooked:
Downloading the app from the web instead of Microsoft Store does not mean they have fewer access to your datas…

Exactly my point. Though I would add that downloading though microsoft is an additional party you would have to put your trust in and they are a major collaborator in the PRISM program

If you do not trust Microsoft, you should run linux on your PC

100% agree. Though I would highly advice people run QubesOS over Ubuntu for security purposes. Though even ubuntu is still infinitely better than any microsoft or apple operating system

Then apple isn’t the best example of spying company, they actually make easier for custormer to know the datas the app takes.

Apple has a long track record of fake privacy promises, and are very hostile to end-users The All-Seeing "i": Apple Just Declared War on Your Privacy

posts.name: Rémy Di Giovanni
posts.cooked:
Then I don’t see why this would be a bad idea, i think this is not the good place to speak about microsoft…

Actually most average user think an app is more trustable or safer if downloaded from a “official” store.
Most people trust Microsoft, my point is not that whether it is true or no, it is that if the app would be more visible then signal would reach more people.
Publishing on the store would not compromise the privacy provided by signal. They are so desperate to get apps on their store that they would not risk not getting a new one by ask the developer (signal) to add tracking modules.

posts.name: Rishi Singhal
posts.cooked: Then just don’t use windows iOS or macOS if it applies to everyone. It is totally illogical to not to bring Signal to MAS or Microsoft store

Since Moxie himself pointed out on several occasions, how much security improvements these closed app stores mean, and that people should download Signal from Google Play, and not as apk…
Is there any reason, which makes the Microsoft Store any different from the Apple App Store or the Google Play Store?
Is the Microsoft Store fundamentally insecure, and thus, the Signal team decided to not bring the Signal app there?

If yes, I think the Signal team should inform the community here, some of whose members spend their valuable time testing beta-versions, about their findings.

If no, I agree it’s not understandable. In this case, it would also make sense to get a short sentence from any developer. Something like:
“Don’t have time right now, we plan Microsoft Store for 2024… bye”

title: Signal Desktop app on the Microsoft Store

accepted_answer.name: Salt
accepted_answer.excerpt:
AboutSignal.com – 30 Jan 26

Signal Desktop now available in the Microsoft Store - AboutSignal.com

Signal Desktop is now also available to Windows users via the Microsoft Store. Downloading via Signal's official website remains possible as well.

Est. reading time: 2 minutes
